block.p: Re ''Free Judges' Pay,'' by Judith S. Kaye (Op-Ed, June 7):
Re ''Free Judges' Pay,'' by Judith S. Kaye (Op-Ed, June 7):
I agree with Chief Judge Kaye on the importance of keeping our ''democracy prosperous and free,'' with ''powers balanced, debts recovered, promises kept and justice done.''
Perhaps the biggest single issue in achieving these goals is equal educational opportunity -- and indeed this has been a major judicial issue in New York State for many years.

In this light, I am struck by Judge Kaye's worry that judges earning a minimum of $136,700 cannot ''afford to continue to live in New York and educate their children.'' Presumably, she means that they cannot afford expensive private educations for their children.
Setting judges' salaries at a level that guarantees their children access to elite educations is not necessarily a good thing.

Perhaps a few judicial offspring in the public schools would have a beneficial effect on suits such as Campaign for Fiscal Equity v. State of New York, which seek adequate, constitutionally mandated financing levels for state schools.
Tom Riordan South Orange, N.J., June 7, 2007
In addition to a pay increase for New York state judges, a bonus should be given to those judges who live in the judicial district in which they serve.

Residing in the judicial area would give the judge an in-depth knowledge of his or her community and provide the community with a sense that the judge is in touch with its activities, problems and dreams.
By the way, a residency bonus should also apply to teachers, police officer and firefighters.
